instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Logic board in good condition.

I don't have the PP3v42 and PPBus line. then I noticed that <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> was burned. I looked for short in the lines and didn't find it. I changed the <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>, same problem, <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> fries (solder is soft). Removed the <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>, I get 17v on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>).

Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/9; <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> is the first suspect there.
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> can also be the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Replaces <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> again, <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> stopped frying! I have 17v on pin 3 of the <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>. But I don't have the 3.42v.

I tried to change the <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and it didn't work.

Diode mode:
<CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> - pin 1 - 0.580
<CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR> - pin 1 - 0.370

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> voltages.
Check its adjacent components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
I switched the <CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, for a few minutes I had 3.49v, a little higher, but no LED on the MagSafe. Now I don't have it again. I checked the component solder. I also tested with another DC card, same thing.

pin 2 - 3.75v
3 - 7.5v
4 - 16.5v
6 - 0
7 - 16.5v
8 - 3.75v
9 - 0
10 - 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message: Forgot to inform. When 3.49v appeared, the PPBus was 12.2v!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Change <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>/6.
Try another <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>; be sure to get good solders.
Also check all traces...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message: I found that when I have the <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> on the board, the somo 3.42 disappears! I changed it, but same problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Probably bad solders, or traces around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
Change the chip again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message: I've already changed the <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> 3x. I soldered the <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> without using air, so as not to mess with the <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, same problem. Without it I have 3.49v, PPBus 12.2v and no MagSafe LED.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Yes, I tried with another <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>. I thought it might be the hot air messing with the <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, so I soldered it with the iron. Same thing.

Sorry, forgot to inform. Yes, I changed the <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>/6.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - component <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> frying
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and check continuity from its pads to all related components.
Just in case, change L6995 too.
